column24: 000 resident yachts.Fort Lauderdale is named after a series of forts built by the United States during the Second Seminole War. The forts took their name from Major William Lauderdale (1782–1838)
column25: younger brother of Lieutenant Colonel James Lauderdale. William Lauderdale was the commander of the detachment of soldiers who built the first fort. Development of the city did not begin until 50 years after the forts were abandoned at the end of the conflict.

column1: Three forts named "Fort Lauderdale" were constructed: the first was at the fork of the New River
column2: the second was at Tarpon Bend on the New River between the present-day Colee Hammock and Rio Vista neighborhoods
column3: and the third was near the site of the Bahia Mar Marina.

column1: The area in which the city of Fort Lauderdale would later be founded was inhabited for more than two thousand years by the Tequesta Indians. Contact with Spanish explorers in the 16th century proved disastrous for the Tequesta
column2: as the Europeans unwittingly brought with them diseases
column3: such as smallpox
column4: to which the native populations possessed no resistance. For the Tequesta
column5: disease
column6: coupled with continuing conflict with their Calusa neighbors
column7: contributed greatly to their decline over the next two centuries. By 1763
column8: there were only a few Tequesta left in Florida
column9: and most of them were evacuated to Cuba when the Spanish ceded Florida to the British in 1763
column10: under the terms of the Treaty of Paris (1763)
column11: which ended the Seven Years' War. Although control of the area changed between Spain
column14: and the Confederate States of America
column15: it remained largely undeveloped until the 20th century.

column1: The Fort Lauderdale area was known as the "New River Settlement" before the 20th century. In the 1830s there were approximately 70 settlers living along the New River. William Cooley
column2: the local Justice of the Peace
column3: was a farmer and wrecker
column4: who traded with the Seminole Indians. On January 6
column6: while Cooley was leading an attempt to salvage a wrecked ship
column7: a band of Seminoles attacked his farm
column9: and the children's tutor. The other farms in the settlement were not attacked
column10: but all the white residents in the area abandoned the settlement
column11: fleeing first to the Cape Florida Lighthouse on Key Biscayne
column12: and then to Key West.The first United States stockade named Fort Lauderdale was built in 1838
column13: and subsequently was a site of fighting during the Second Seminole War. The fort was abandoned in 1842
column14: after the end of the war
column15: and the area remained virtually unpopulated until the 1890s. It was not until Frank Stranahan arrived in the area in 1893 to operate a ferry across the New River
column16: and the Florida East Coast Railroad's completion of a route through the area in 1896
column17: that any organized development began. The city was incorporated in 1911
column18: and in 1915 was designated the county seat of newly formed Broward County.Fort Lauderdale's first major development began in the 1920s
column19: during the Florida land boom. The 1926 Miami Hurricane and the Great Depression of the 1930s caused a great deal of economic dislocation. In July 1935
column20: an African-American man named Rubin Stacy was accused of robbing a white woman at knife point. He was arrested and being transported to a Miami jail when police were run off the road by a mob. A group of 100 white men proceeded to hang Stacy from a tree near the scene of his alleged robbery. His body was riddled with some twenty bullets. The murder was subsequently used by the press in Nazi Germany to discredit U.S. critiques of its own persecution of Jews
column22: and Catholics.When World War II began
column23: Fort Lauderdale became a major U.S. base
column24: with a Naval Air Station to train pilots
column26: and fire control operators. A Coast Guard base at Port Everglades was also established.Until July 1961 only whites were allowed on Ft. Lauderdale beaches. There were no beaches for African-Americans in Broward County until 1954

column1: According to the Köppen climate classification
column2: Fort Lauderdale has a trade-wind tropical rainforest (Köppen Af). While the city does not have a true dry season
column3: much of the seasonal rainfall comes between May and October. Winters are frequently dry and sunny
column4: and drought can be a concern in some years. (see climate chart below).

column1: The wet season runs from May through October
column2: and weather is typically hot
column3: humid
column4: and wet with average high temperatures of 86–90 °F (30–32 °C) and lows of 71–76 °F (22–24 °C). During this period
column5: more than half of summer days may bring brief afternoon or evening thunderstorms with lightning and bursts of intense rainfall. The record high temperature of 100 °F (38 °C) was recorded on June 22
column6: 2009.The dry season often arrives some time in November and lasts through early to mid April. Sensible weather is often warm
column8: and sunny. Average high temperatures of 75–82 °F (24–28 °C) and lows of 59–67 °F (15–19 °C) are typical in the dry season. On rare occasion
column9: cool fronts may make it all the way south to Fort Lauderdale and the city will see a day or two of highs in the 60s °F (16-21 °C) and lows in the 40s °F (4-10 °C).  Rare frosts occur every few decades
column10: and only once in recorded history have snow flurries been reported in the air
column13: brush fires can be a concern in many years.

column1: Fort Lauderdale has a Commission-Manager form of government. City policy is set by a city commission of five elected members: the mayor and four district commission members. In 1998
column2: the municipal code was amended to limit the mayoral term. The mayor of Fort Lauderdale now serves a three-year term and cannot serve more than three consecutive terms. The current mayor is Dean Trantalis
column3: who succeeded Jack Seiler in 2018. The longest-serving mayor is Jim Naugle
column4: who served from 1991 to 2009. Administrative functions are performed by a city manager
column5: who is appointed by the city commission. Fort Lauderdale Fire-Rescue Department provides Fire and Emergency Medical Services.
